questions.text: A 60-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70 beats/min, arterial pressure is 130/85 mm Hg, and body temperature is normal. Her pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is shown below. When does the second heart sound occur in the ventricular pressure–volume relationship?

options.label: B
options.text: Between point A and point B

options.label: C
options.text: Between point B and point C

options.label: D
options.text: Between point C and point D

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) At point D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The second heart sound (S2) occurs at point D of the pressure-volume loop, corresponding to closure of the aortic valve at the end of systole. It marks the beginning of isovolumetric relaxation of the left ventricle.
  • ➤ The second heart sound (S2) occurs at point D of the pressure-volume loop, corresponding to closure of the aortic valve at the end of systole.
  • ➤ second heart sound (S2)
  • ➤ point D
  • ➤ closure of the aortic valve
  • ➤ It marks the beginning of isovolumetric relaxation of the left ventricle.
  • ➤ isovolumetric relaxation

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios is least likely to violate Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium?

options.label: A
options.text: Founder effect in an island population

options.label: B
options.text: Introduction of new alleles due to migration

options.label: C
options.text: Random mating within a large gene pool

options.label: D
options.text: Increased survival of heterozygotes compared to homozygotes

questions.correct_answer: C. Random mating within a large gene pool
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Random mating within a large gene pool

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Random mating in a large gene pool is a core assumption of Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium and is least likely to violate it, while evolutionary forces such as migration, selection, and genetic drift cause significant deviations.
  • ➤ Random mating in a large gene pool
  • ➤ migration, selection, and genetic drift

questions.text: Which enzyme is not involved in shuttling fatty acids into the mitochondrial matrix for β-oxidation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acyl Co-A dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The carnitine shuttle system, is essential for the mitochondrial import of long-chain fatty acids. Key enzymes involved include CPT I, CPT II, and the translocase. Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase is not involved in transport—it functions after the fatty acid enters the matrix, initiating β-oxidation.
  • ➤ The carnitine shuttle system, is essential for the mitochondrial import of long-chain fatty acids.
  • ➤ Key enzymes involved include CPT I, CPT II, and the translocase.
  • ➤ Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase is not involved in transport—it functions after the fatty acid enters the matrix, initiating β-oxidation.

questions.text: A malnourished patient presents with symptoms of fatigue, muscle weakness, and neurological impairment. Laboratory investigations suggest decreased energy production due to a vitamin deficiency. The deficiency affects thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), which plays a crucial role in energy metabolism. Which of the following best explains how TPP deficiency leads to reduced ATP production?

options.label: B
options.text: TPP is a coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

options.label: C
options.text: TPP interferes with energy production from amino acids

questions.correct_answer: B. TPP is a coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) TPP is a coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiamine deficiency leads to impaired energy production because TPP serves as a coenzyme for pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, enzymes essential for aerobic glucose metabolism and ATP synthesis.

questions.text: Assertion (A): Reverse triage is often applied in military or disaster settings to prioritize the most severely wounded for treatment. Reason (R): This strategy ensures that scarce medical resources are reserved for those with the highest survival chances.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A

options.label: C
options.text: A is false, but R is true

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and R are false

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reverse triage is a strategic method used in mass casualty, war, or resource-scarce settings where those most likely to benefit from limited resources are prioritized , often deferring care for the critically injured.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy of the nasopharynx are true? Thornwaldt cyst arises from the same area as the nasopharyngeal bursa, which is a remnant of the notochord. The fossa of Rosenmuller is located anterior to the torus tubarius and is the most common site of origin of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). The sphenopalatine foramen is formed by the pterygoid part of sphenoid bone and the perpendicular plate of palatine bone. The pterygopalatine fossa connects laterally with the infratemporal fossa via the pterygomaxillary fissure and medially with the nasopharynx via the sphenopalatine foramen. Passavant’s ridge helps in preventing nasal regurgitation during swallowing by separating nasopharynx from oropharynx.

options.label: A
options.text: Only A, C, D and E are true

options.label: B
options.text: Only A, B and C are true

options.label: C
options.text: Only B, C and D are true

options.label: D
options.text: All statements (A to E) are true

questions.correct_answer: A. Only A, C, D and E are true
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Only A, C, D and E are true

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thornwaldt cyst originates from the nasopharyngeal bursa, a remnant of the notochord. Fossa of Rosenmuller is posterior to torus tubarius and is the common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, not JNA. JNA arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. Sphenopalatine foramen is formed by pterygoid part of sphenoid and perpendicular plate of palatine bone. Pterygopalatine fossa connects medially to nasopharynx (via sphenopalatine foramen) and laterally to infratemporal fossa (via pterygomaxillary fissure). Passavant’s ridge blocks nasopharynx during swallowing, preventing nasal regurgitation.
  • ➤ Thornwaldt cyst originates from the nasopharyngeal bursa, a remnant of the notochord.
  • ➤ Fossa of Rosenmuller is posterior to torus tubarius and is the common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, not JNA. JNA arises from the sphenopalatine foramen.
  • ➤ Sphenopalatine foramen is formed by pterygoid part of sphenoid and perpendicular plate of palatine bone.
  • ➤ Pterygopalatine fossa connects medially to nasopharynx (via sphenopalatine foramen) and laterally to infratemporal fossa (via pterygomaxillary fissure).
  • ➤ Passavant’s ridge blocks nasopharynx during swallowing, preventing nasal regurgitation.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with right lower quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis for the past 3 days. Imaging reveals an ill-defined inflammatory mass in the right lower abdomen, consistent with appendicular phlegmon. What is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Antibiotics and observation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Appendicular phlegmon refers to a localized inflammatory mass resulting from acute appendicitis. It forms when the inflamed appendix is surrounded by adjacent organs, omentum, and bowel loops, effectively "walling off" the infection to prevent widespread peritonitis. The initial approach involves conservative treatment with antibiotics and observation. This helps reduce inflammation and allows the phlegmon to resolve. After recovery, elective appendectomy is recommended to prevent recurrence.
  • ➤ Appendicular phlegmon refers to a localized inflammatory mass resulting from acute appendicitis. It forms when the inflamed appendix is surrounded by adjacent organs, omentum, and bowel loops, effectively "walling off" the infection to prevent widespread peritonitis.
  • ➤ The initial approach involves conservative treatment with antibiotics and observation. This helps reduce inflammation and allows the phlegmon to resolve. After recovery, elective appendectomy is recommended to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following infections listed by WHO as likely to cause future major epidemics shares the most epidemiological characteristics with Zika virus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rift Valley fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Among WHO-listed high-risk emerging infections, Rift Valley fever shares the closest epidemiologic resemblance to Zika virus, particularly due to mosquito-borne transmission, zoonotic nature, and potential to cause vertical transmission and fetal abnormalities.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with a slowly enlarging neck mass and symptoms of fatigue and cold intolerance. On physical examination, her thyroid is firm, immobile, and described as "hard as wood." The gland is nontender, and there is evidence of mild tracheal deviation. Laboratory testing shows elevated TSH and low free T4. Imaging reveals fibrosis extending into surrounding neck structures. A biopsy demonstrates dense fibrosis and chronic inflammation without atypical cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Riedel fibrosing thyroiditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Riedel fibrosing thyroiditis presents as a " hard as wood " nontender thyroid with fibrosis that may invade surrounding structures; it mimics anaplastic carcinoma but occurs in younger patients and lacks malignant cells.
  • ➤ hard as wood

questions.text: Which of the following is not a distinctive characteristic of a typical cervical vertebra?

options.label: A
options.text: The body is small and wider from side to side than anteroposteriorly

options.label: B
options.text: The vertebral foramen is large and triangular

options.label: C
options.text: The transverse processes contain transverse foramina

options.label: D
options.text: The articular processes contain superior facets directed inferoanteriorly

questions.correct_answer: D. The articular processes contain superior facets directed inferoanteriorly
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The articular processes contain superior facets directed inferoanteriorly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Typical cervical vertebrae (C3–C6) are characterized by small bodies , bifid spinous processes , foramina transversaria , and large triangular vertebral foramina . Their superior articular facets are directed superoposteriorly , which is critical for their functional biomechanics. Misidentifying the facet orientation can lead to confusion with thoracic or lumbar vertebrae.
  • ➤ Typical cervical vertebrae (C3–C6) are characterized by small bodies , bifid spinous processes , foramina transversaria , and large triangular vertebral foramina .
  • ➤ small bodies
  • ➤ bifid spinous processes
  • ➤ foramina transversaria
  • ➤ large triangular vertebral foramina
  • ➤ Their superior articular facets are directed superoposteriorly , which is critical for their functional biomechanics.
  • ➤ superior articular facets
  • ➤ superoposteriorly
  • ➤ Misidentifying the facet orientation can lead to confusion with thoracic or lumbar vertebrae.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child with developmental delay is brought in due to behavioral disturbances. On examination, he has multiple scars on lips and hands, consistent with self-mutilation. There is a positive family history of a similar condition in a male relative. Which of the following laboratory tests would be most valuable in guiding diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Uric acid

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked disorder of purine metabolism due to HGPRT deficiency, and is characterized by self-mutilation, neurological symptoms, and hyperuricemia. Measurement of uric acid is the most important diagnostic test.

questions.text: In a region with a total population of 10,000 individuals, serological surveys show that 7,500 individuals have antibodies to a particular infection. If the infection is in an endemic steady state, what is the basic reproduction number (R₀) for this infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 4.0

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To test the application of the endemic steady state formula R₀ × S = 1, reinforcing how immunity levels in the population (e.g., post-infection or vaccination) influence transmission dynamics of infections. In endemic conditions, the product of R₀ and proportion susceptible (S) must equal 1 . Knowing the immunity status of the population allows you to back-calculate R₀ , which is vital for forecasting and control of infectious diseases.
  • ➤ To test the application of the endemic steady state formula R₀ × S = 1, reinforcing how immunity levels in the population (e.g., post-infection or vaccination) influence transmission dynamics of infections.
  • ➤ endemic steady state formula
  • ➤ In endemic conditions, the product of R₀ and proportion susceptible (S) must equal 1 . Knowing the immunity status of the population allows you to back-calculate R₀ , which is vital for forecasting and control of infectious diseases.
  • ➤ R₀
  • ➤ proportion susceptible
  • ➤ 1
  • ➤ back-calculate R₀

questions.text: A previously healthy 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with high-grade fever, headache, nausea, and neck stiffness. He rapidly develops altered mental status.   • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Naegleria fowleri causes rapidly progressive primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), diagnosed by identifying motile trophozoites in CSF wet mount in an acutely ill patient.

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the muscle whose paralysis leads to this sign?

questions.text: A primigravida woman reports to the health subcenter at 9 months of pregnancy (POG) with no prior antenatal visits or Td immunization. The ANM suggests giving one Td dose due to anticipated early labor. The medical officer (MO) intervenes. Which is the most appropriate public health action, assuming delivery is likely within 3 days?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer 2 doses of Td—one now and one 1 month later

options.label: B
options.text: Administer a single Td dose only

options.label: C
options.text: Defer Td until after delivery and administer 2 doses 1 month apart

options.label: D
options.text: Administer one Td dose and 750 IU antitoxin post-delivery for neonatal protection

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old athlete undergoes intense physical exercise without proper hydration. During this period, significant sweating occurs. A graphical representation of his body fluid compartments and osmolarity is obtained. Which of the following best describes the type of body fluid disturbance in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypoosmotic fluid loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sweating leads to a hyperosmotic volume contraction due to loss of hypoosmotic sweat. This results in decreased ECF and ICF volumes with increased osmolarity. Such disturbances must be corrected by water intake with electrolyte replacement to restore fluid balance.
  • ➤ Sweating leads to a hyperosmotic volume contraction due to loss of hypoosmotic sweat.
  • ➤ Sweating leads to a hyperosmotic volume contraction
  • ➤ This results in decreased ECF and ICF volumes with increased osmolarity.
  • ➤ Such disturbances must be corrected by water intake with electrolyte replacement to restore fluid balance.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents on the third day of high-grade fever, myalgia, retro-orbital pain, and a diffuse maculopapular rash. Dengue fever is suspected based on clinical grounds. Which of the following diagnostic methods is least appropriate for confirmation of dengue infection at this stage of illness?

options.text: Isolation of virus in Aedes albopictus C6/36 cell culture

options.label: C

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During the early phase of dengue infection (days 1–5), direct detection methods such as NS1 antigen, RT-PCR, and viral culture are appropriate; IgM ELISA is not useful this early, as antibodies typically appear after day 5.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with intermenstrual bleeding. On speculum examination, a friable, cauliflower-like lesion is observed on the cervix. The lesion bleeds on touch. questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Punch biopsy forceps

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with visible cervical lesions and abnormal bleeding, punch biopsy using biopsy forceps is the investigation of choice. Cytological tools like spatulas and brushes are used in screening but are inadequate for diagnosing invasive disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the biochemical properties of Shigella species are incorrect? All Shigella species are non-motile. questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of confusion. Over the past week, she had increasing dysuria and left-sided flank pain. questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presents with redness in one eye that has developed gradually over a few days. There is no significant pain, and vision is unaffected. questions.text: Assertion (A): Zoledronic acid helps reduce bone breakdown and fracture risk in patients with osteoporosis. Reason (R): Zoledronic acid is a bisphosphonate that binds to hydroxyapatite and stimulates osteoblast activity to promote bone formation.

options.label: A
options.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A

options.label: B
options.text: Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A

options.label: C
options.text: A is true, but R is false

options.label: D
options.text: A is false, but R is true

questions.correct_answer: C. A is true, but R is false
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A is true, but R is false

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with progressive shortness of breath and decreased exercise tolerance. He has never smoked. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance to percussion. Pulmonary function tests show an obstructive pattern. A liver biopsy shows pink, PAS-positive globules in hepatocytes. Which of the following best explains the underlying cause of this patient's disease? Excess elastase activity causes centriacinar emphysema predominantly in the upper lobes. Mutated antiprotease accumulates in the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes, resulting in liver damage and panacinar emphysema. Chronic tobacco smoke exposure increases goblet cell hyperplasia and submucosal gland hypertrophy. Autoimmune destruction of alveolar walls leads to honeycombing of the lung bases. Bronchial obstruction leads to air trapping and recurrent infections with mucus plugging.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alpha-1 antitrypsin (A1AT) deficiency causes panacinar emphysema (most severe in the lower lobes) and liver cirrhosis due to misfolded A1AT protein accumulating in the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes, seen as pink, PAS-positive globules on biopsy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of hypertension is being considered for a new antihypertensive medication. questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with severe, deep, boring pain and redness in the left eye. The pain is persistent and intense enough to disturb sleep. Ocular ultrasonography (B-scan) reveals a ‘T-sign’ involving the outer coats of the eyeball. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Staphylococcus aureus-specific enzymes are incorrect? The coagulase test is used to differentiate S. aureus from coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS). Thermonuclease produced by S. aureus is heat-stable and can digest DNA. The DNase test is positive in both S. aureus and CoNS species. Phosphatase activity is absent in S. aureus, which differentiates it from other Gram-positive cocci. questions.text: Match the Following: Maneuvers for Shoulder Dystocia and Their Descriptions: Column A (Maneuver) McRoberts maneuver Suprapubic pressure Rubin II maneuver Woods’ screw maneuver Gaskin maneuver Column B (Description) Rotation of the anterior shoulder to posterior to dislodge impacted shoulder Maternal hip hyperflexion to flatten the lumbar spine and widen pelvic outlet Posterior-directed pressure on the anterior shoulder to move fetus into oblique angle Changing maternal position to hands-and-knees to increase pelvic dimensions Pressure applied over pubic area toward the posterior aspect of fetal anterior shoulder
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A–2, B–5, C–3, D–1, E–4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A–2. McRoberts maneuver: Involves hyperflexion of the maternal hips onto the abdomen to flatten the lumbar spine and widen the pelvic outlet.
  • • A–2. McRoberts maneuver:
  • • B–5. Suprapubic pressure: Pressure is directed posteriorly and laterally over the pubic area to assist in dislodging the anterior fetal shoulder.
  • • B–5. Suprapubic pressure:
  • • C–3. Rubin II maneuver: Posterior-directed pressure on the anterior fetal shoulder to rotate it into an oblique plane.
  • • C–3. Rubin II maneuver:
  • • D–1. Woods’ screw maneuver: Simultaneous pressure on the posterior shoulder to rotate the fetus, effectively turning the anterior shoulder to the posterior.
  • • D–1. Woods’ screw maneuver:
  • • E–4. Gaskin maneuver: Positioning the mother on all fours (hands and knees), increasing pelvic dimensions and facilitating delivery.
  • • E–4. Gaskin maneuver:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency that requires prompt maneuvering to release the impacted fetal shoulder. A systematic approach using well-established maneuvers—such as McRoberts, suprapubic pressure, Rubin II, Woods' screw, and Gaskin—is essential to safely resolve the obstruction and minimize fetal and maternal morbidity.
  • ➤ Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency that requires prompt maneuvering to release the impacted fetal shoulder.
  • ➤ A systematic approach using well-established maneuvers—such as McRoberts, suprapubic pressure, Rubin II, Woods' screw, and Gaskin—is essential to safely resolve the obstruction and minimize fetal and maternal morbidity.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, known case of cirrhosis of the liver, presents with an abdominal lump. questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding amyloidosis is/are correct? Amyloidosis is characterized by the extracellular deposition of abnormal protein fibrils that interfere with normal tissue function. X-ray crystallography can detect the presence of beta-pleated sheet conformations, which are a hallmark of amyloid fibrils. The primary form of amyloidosis, known as AL amyloidosis, occurs due to an accumulation of amyloid deposits secondary to chronic inflammation. The extracellular amyloid deposits primarily consist of misfolded proteins that accumulate within cells, leading to organ dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Serine Hydroxy Methyl Transferase (SHMT) are incorrect? Serine Hydroxy Methyl Transferase belongs to the class II group of enzymes. The enzyme catalyzes an irreversible reaction converting serine to glycine. Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) and folic acid derivatives are essential cofactors for this enzyme’s activity. The conversion of serine to glycine involves the donation of the β-carbon of serine to tetrahydrofolate (THFA). The α-carbon of serine is donated to THFA during the reaction.

questions.text: A researcher is evaluating the reliability of a newly developed 10-item self-report scale intended to measure depressive symptoms in a college population. Upon running an internal consistency analysis, she finds that the Cronbach’s alpha for the entire scale is 0.78. However, when item 7 is removed, the Cronbach’s alpha increases to 0.82. options.text: Item 7 may not align well with the overall construct and could be considered for removal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Such items should be carefully reviewed or revised to improve scale reliability.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, Mr. Sharma without any relevant past medical history, visits Dr Singh in a hospital with abdominal discomfort. His family sues Dr. Singh and the hospital for medical negligence, alleging failure to order cardiac tests. Who bears the onus of proof in this civil negligence case?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient's family (plaintiffs), because they are accusing the doctor of negligence

options.label: B
options.text: Dr. Singh, because he must prove that his clinical decision was based on standard medical practice

options.label: C
options.text: The hospital, because it is the employer and responsible for the actions of its staff under vicarious liability

options.label: D
options.text: Shared between the patient's family and the hospital, as both need to provide evidence to support or refute the claim

questions.correct_answer: A. The patient's family (plaintiffs), because they are accusing the doctor of negligence

Ans. A) The patient's family (plaintiffs), because they are accusing the doctor of negligence.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In civil medical negligence cases, the burden of proof lies with the plaintiff , who must establish that:
  • ➤ burden of proof lies with the plaintiff
  • ➤ A duty of care existed, There was a breach of that duty, The breach caused the harm. The defendant (doctor or hospital) is not required to prove innocence unless rebutting the presented claim.
  • ➤ A duty of care existed,
  • ➤ There was a breach of that duty,
  • ➤ The breach caused the harm. The defendant (doctor or hospital) is not required to prove innocence unless rebutting the presented claim.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with a 30-pack-year smoking history (quit 7 years ago) is asymptomatic and presents for preventive care. Which of the following is the most appropriate screening test for lung cancer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Annual low-dose CT scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LDCT is the only validated screening tool to reduce lung cancer mortality in patients with significant smoking history.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman reports 6 years of daily green sputum, frequent sinus infections, and occasional hemoptysis. Lung auscultation reveals coarse crackles. Spirometry shows FEV₁/FVC = 54%. Sputum grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa. What is the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) High-resolution CT scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HRCT is the preferred diagnostic test for bronchiectasis in patients with recurrent infections and chronic sputum production.

questions.text: A 6-month-old female infant is brought for evaluation of refractory infantile spasms and delayed milestones. The child was born at term with no perinatal complications. MRI brain is as shown below. Which of the following findings, if present, would most strongly argue against the diagnosis of Aicardi Syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 46, XY karyotype

questions.text: A 30-year-old man drinks daily and reports hangovers and one blackout. He denies social or legal issues. Which lab markers best detect chronic heavy alcohol use?

options.label: B
options.text: Carbohydrate Deficient Transferrin >2.6% and elevated GGT

questions.correct_answer: B. Carbohydrate Deficient Transferrin >2.6% and elevated GGT
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Carbohydrate Deficient Transferrin >2.6% and elevated GGT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For detecting covert alcohol use, CDT and GGT together offer optimal sensitivity and specificity among lab tests.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with a history of chronic kidney disease stage 3 and long-standing hypertension is found to have recurrent episodes of hyperkalemia during routine lab monitoring. He is currently taking an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor as part of his antihypertensive regimen. Which of the following diuretics is the most suitable choice to address his blood pressure and electrolyte imbalance?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Furosemide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Furosemide is the preferred diuretic in patients with stage 3 chronic kidney disease and recurrent hyperkalemia, particularly when they are receiving an ACE inhibitor .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, presents for a routine antenatal visit at 32 weeks of gestation. Her previous pregnancy was uneventful. On examination, her symphysis-fundal height is found to be lagging by 4 weeks. An obstetric ultrasound confirms fetal growth restriction (FGR) with an estimated fetal weight below the 10th percentile for gestational age. Umbilical artery Doppler is as follows. Fetal heart rate is 146 bpm. She is otherwise asymptomatic and has no signs of preeclampsia. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Corticosteroids followed by induction of labor

questions.correct_answer: D. Weekly Doppler of umbilical artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Weekly Doppler of umbilical artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In early-onset FGR with normal Doppler flow , the best approach is weekly umbilical artery Doppler monitoring . Early intervention is considered only if Doppler findings worsen or other complications develop.
  • ➤ In early-onset FGR with normal Doppler flow , the best approach is weekly umbilical artery Doppler monitoring .
  • ➤ early-onset FGR
  • ➤ normal Doppler flow
  • ➤ weekly umbilical artery Doppler monitoring
  • ➤ Early intervention is considered only if Doppler findings worsen or other complications develop.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student presents with fever, sore throat, generalized lymphadenopathy, and fatigue. Monospot test is negative, but Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) serology is sent to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following antibodies, if present, would indicate a past EBV infection rather than an acute one?

options.label: B
options.text: Antibody to viral capsid antigen (VCA) IgM

questions.correct_answer: C. Antibody to EBV nuclear antigen (EBNA)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Antibody to EBV nuclear antigen (EBNA)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Antibodies to EBV nuclear antigen (EBNA) are detected only after the acute phase and persist lifelong, serving as a marker of past EBV infection.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female presents to the emergency department after a fall from standing height. She is unable to bear weight on her right leg and reports severe hip pain. On examination, the right leg appears shortened and externally rotated. The patient has a history of osteoporosis and is currently on long-term corticosteroid therapy for rheumatoid arthritis. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Non-weight bearing with follow-up X-ray in 6 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Initiate weight-bearing with analgesics and physical therapy

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hip replacement surgery

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with upper abdominal discomfort, dark stools, and relief with antacids. Endoscopy reveals a 2.2 cm duodenal ulcer and positive H. pylori biopsy. Which of the following is not an appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pantoprazole and Clarithromycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Effective H. pylori treatment requires at least two antibiotics and a PPI; dual regimens without this are inadequate.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with gradually progressive patchy hair loss over the scalp for the past 4 months. On examination, the scalp shows well-demarcated erythematous plaques with adherent scales. When one of the scales is gently lifted, multiple horny projections are seen on its underside that had been lodged within the follicular openings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Discoid lupus erythematosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The carpet tack sign —seen when scales from DLE lesions are removed—is a clinical clue to follicular plugging and chronic scarring alopecia. Recognizing this sign is important in distinguishing DLE from other causes of hair loss.
  • ➤ The carpet tack sign —seen when scales from DLE lesions are removed—is a clinical clue to follicular plugging and chronic scarring alopecia.
  • ➤ carpet tack sign
  • ➤ Recognizing this sign is important in distinguishing DLE from other causes of hair loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is primarily responsible for the change in membrane potential between points B and D?

options.label: B
options.text: Movement of K⁺ into the cell

options.label: C
options.text: Movement of K⁺ out of the cell

options.label: D
options.text: Movement of Na⁺ into the cell

questions.correct_answer: D. Movement of Na⁺ into the cell
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Movement of Na⁺ into the cell

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During the depolarization phase of an action potential, voltage-gated Na⁺ channels open , allowing Na⁺ to flow into the cell . This inward current causes the membrane potential to rapidly become more positive, a hallmark of the rising phase of the action potential.
  • ➤ During the depolarization phase of an action potential, voltage-gated Na⁺ channels open , allowing Na⁺ to flow into the cell .
  • ➤ voltage-gated Na⁺ channels open
  • ➤ Na⁺ to flow into the cell
  • ➤ This inward current causes the membrane potential to rapidly become more positive, a hallmark of the rising phase of the action potential.
  • ➤ inward current
  • ➤ rising phase

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with fatigue, weight loss, and mild abdominal fullness. Examination reveals splenomegaly. Laboratory tests show lymphocytosis. Lymph node biopsy reveals a population of CD5-positive B cells with overexpression of cyclin D1. Genetic analysis identifies a t(11;14) translocation involving the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) locus and the CCND1 gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mantle cell lymphoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mantle cell lymphoma is defined by a t(11;14) translocation involving the CCND1 gene and the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) locus, resulting in cyclin D1 overexpression and dysregulated cell cycle progression.

questions.text: A lethal mutation in a bacterium results in the inability to properly replicate its chromosome. DNA synthesis is initiated, but the process yields numerous short DNA fragments, each containing an RNA segment at their 5′ ends. This mutation is most likely affecting a gene encoding which of the following enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) DNA polymerase I

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DNA polymerase I in prokaryotes removes RNA primers from Okazaki fragments and replaces them with DNA . A mutation impairing this function leads to the accumulation of short DNA fragments with RNA at their 5′ ends , disrupting chromosome replication.
  • ➤ DNA polymerase I in prokaryotes removes RNA primers from Okazaki fragments and replaces them with DNA .
  • ➤ DNA polymerase I
  • ➤ RNA primers
  • ➤ DNA
  • ➤ A mutation impairing this function leads to the accumulation of short DNA fragments with RNA at their 5′ ends , disrupting chromosome replication.
  • ➤ short DNA fragments with RNA at their 5′ ends

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman, G4P3 at 28 weeks of gestation, presents with recurrent episodes of painless vaginal bleeding over the past 1 week. Her medical history is significant for 1 previous cesarean delivery and 1 dilatation and curettage of a previous incomplete abortion. On examination, her vital signs are stable, and the fetal heart rate is reassuring. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a placenta located near the cervix with multiple hypoechoic areas and irregular vascular spaces within the placenta. Laboratory results show an Hb of 8g%. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate cesarean followed by bilateral internal iliac artery ligation

options.label: B
options.text: Administration of corticosteroids, transfuse blood, followed by a planned cesarean at 37 weeks.

options.label: C
options.text: Serial ultrasound monitoring with plans of delivery if evidence of increasing vascularity in the placenta

options.label: D
options.text: Admit, transfuse blood, give steroids and plan an elective cesarean delivery with hysterectomy at 36 weeks of pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: D. Admit, transfuse blood, give steroids and plan an elective cesarean delivery with hysterectomy at 36 weeks of pregnancy
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Admit, transfuse blood, give steroids and plan an elective cesarean delivery with hysterectomy at 36 weeks of pregnancy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment of placenta accreta syndromes includes: Stabilization of the patient Planning an elective cesarean delivery (preferably a classical cesarean) at 34-37 weeks, leaving the placenta in situ followed by a hysterectomy as any attempts to remove an adherent placenta result in severe hemorrhage.
  • ➤ Treatment of placenta accreta syndromes includes: Stabilization of the patient Planning an elective cesarean delivery (preferably a classical cesarean) at 34-37 weeks, leaving the placenta in situ followed by a hysterectomy as any attempts to remove an adherent placenta result in severe hemorrhage.
  • ➤ Stabilization of the patient Planning an elective cesarean delivery (preferably a classical cesarean) at 34-37 weeks, leaving the placenta in situ followed by a hysterectomy as any attempts to remove an adherent placenta result in severe hemorrhage.
  • ➤ Stabilization of the patient
  • ➤ Planning an elective cesarean delivery (preferably a classical cesarean) at 34-37 weeks, leaving the placenta in situ followed by a hysterectomy as any attempts to remove an adherent placenta result in severe hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 35-year-old intelligence officer is undergoing screening to ensure loyalty and integrity before receiving a high-security clearance. Investigators decide to use a method based on measuring brain recognition signals, which is unaffected by emotional reactions. Which of the following best differentiates brain fingerprinting from polygraph testing?

options.label: A
options.text: Brain fingerprinting measures heart rate variability

options.label: C
options.text: Brain fingerprinting detects cognitive memory-based responses

options.label: D
options.text: Brain fingerprinting determines truthfulness through galvanic skin response

questions.correct_answer: C. Brain fingerprinting detects cognitive memory-based responses
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Brain fingerprinting detects cognitive memory-based responses

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Unlike polygraphy, which depends on emotional and autonomic responses (e.g., heart rate, sweating), brain fingerprinting directly measures brain recognition responses (P300 and MERMER) to known information, offering a more objective tool for detecting concealed knowledge .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is diagnosed with congenital glaucoma and is initiated on medical therapy while awaiting surgical intervention. The ophthalmology team considers several topical antiglaucoma agents. Which of the following medications is contraindicated or unsafe in infants due to the risk of serious central nervous system side effects?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Brimonidine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brimonidine is contraindicated in infants due to its potential to cause serious CNS depression, including apnea, hypotension, and coma.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with progressive muscle weakness undergoes pulmonary function testing. She has tested positive for AchRAb and repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response. Which pattern in pulmonary function testing best corresponds to the suspected diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased TLC, reduced VC, low FEV₁/FVC ratio

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced TLC, RV, and VC; high FEV₁/FVC; normal MIP

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced TLC, increased RV, normal FEV₁/FVC ratio, low MIP

options.label: D
options.text: Normal TLC, RV, FEV₁/FVC, and MIP

questions.correct_answer: C. Reduced TLC, increased RV, normal FEV₁/FVC ratio, low MIP
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reduced TLC, increased RV, normal FEV₁/FVC ratio, low MIP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neuromuscular diseases like myasthenia gravis show a restrictive pattern on PFTs with low TLC, increased RV, normal FEV₁/FVC, and low MIP—reflecting inspiratory muscle weakness and ineffective expiration.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is prescribed mirtazapine for major depressive disorder. After a few days, he reports excessive sleepiness, increased appetite, and noticeable weight gain. These side effects are most likely due to mirtazapine's antagonistic action at which of the following receptors?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Histamine H1 receptors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mirtazapine is a noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant (NaSSA) with a unique receptor profile. Its antidepressant and side effect profile is due to actions at multiple receptor sites: α2-adrenergic antagonism → Increases norepinephrine and serotonin release, enhancing antidepressant effect. 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 antagonism → Reduces anxiety, GI symptoms, and sexual side effects. H1 histamine receptor antagonism → Causes sedation, increased appetite, and weight gain.
  • ➤ Mirtazapine is a noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant (NaSSA) with a unique receptor profile. Its antidepressant and side effect profile is due to actions at multiple receptor sites: α2-adrenergic antagonism → Increases norepinephrine and serotonin release, enhancing antidepressant effect. 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 antagonism → Reduces anxiety, GI symptoms, and sexual side effects. H1 histamine receptor antagonism → Causes sedation, increased appetite, and weight gain.
  • ➤ Mirtazapine
  • ➤ noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant (NaSSA)
  • ➤ α2-adrenergic antagonism → Increases norepinephrine and serotonin release, enhancing antidepressant effect. 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 antagonism → Reduces anxiety, GI symptoms, and sexual side effects. H1 histamine receptor antagonism → Causes sedation, increased appetite, and weight gain.
  • ➤ α2-adrenergic antagonism → Increases norepinephrine and serotonin release, enhancing antidepressant effect.
  • ➤ α2-adrenergic antagonism
  • ➤ 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 antagonism → Reduces anxiety, GI symptoms, and sexual side effects.
  • ➤ 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 antagonism
  • ➤ H1 histamine receptor antagonism → Causes sedation, increased appetite, and weight gain.
  • ➤ H1 histamine receptor antagonism

questions.text: A 5-year-old male is brought in due to increasing fatigue and bruising over the past few weeks. On evaluation, he appears pale and has multiple petechiae over his lower extremities. He also has palpable cervical and axillary lymph nodes. Lab results reveal hemoglobin of 8.0 g/dL, platelet count of 40,000/µL, and white blood cell count of 120,000/µL. A peripheral smear reveals numerous blasts, and flow cytometry identifies the blasts as TdT-positive, CD10-positive, and CD19-positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia B subtype
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia B subtype

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute lymphoblastic leukemia B subtype is identified by TdT, CD10, and CD19 positivity and is the most common malignancy in children presenting with anemia, thrombocytopenia, lymphadenopathy, and blasts in peripheral blood.

questions.text: Match the following brain areas and their functions: Column A (Brain Area) Wernicke’s Area Broca’s Area Angular Gyrus Postcentral Gyrus Column B (Function) Speech production Language comprehension Processing of written language Primary somatosensory processing
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A–2, B–1, C–3, D–4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Different regions of the brain are specialized for specific aspects of language and sensory function . Wernicke’s area is key for language comprehension, while Broca’s area enables speech production. The angular gyrus plays a role in reading and writing, and the postcentral gyrus is responsible for primary somatic sensation.

questions.text: An outbreak of acute gastroenteritis has been reported in a community following a public event. Multiple individuals presented with fever, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. Stool specimens have been collected and sent to the microbiology laboratory to isolate the likely causative organism, Salmonella spp. Which of the following enrichment media is most appropriate to facilitate the isolation of Salmonella from stool samples in this context?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Selenite F broth

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Selenite F broth is the enrichment medium of choice for isolating Salmonella from stool samples, especially in suspected outbreaks of foodborne gastroenteritis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man experiences an anaphylactic reaction and receives a subcutaneous injection of epinephrine, which is the standard first-line treatment due to its vasoconstrictive (α1) and bronchodilatory (β2) effects. However, instead of vasoconstriction, the patient develops further vasodilation after the injection. Which of the following medications is the patient most likely already taking, thereby interfering with the expected response to epinephrine?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ergotamine for migraine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epinephrine produces vasodilation when administered in the presence of an alpha-adrenergic blocker like ergotamine due to unopposed beta-2 receptor-mediated effects, a phenomenon known as vasomotor reversal of Dale.

questions.text: A newly industrializing country conducts a demographic review and finds that its Annual Growth Rate (AGR) is 0.6%. Based on standard classifications of population growth patterns, which of the following statements best reflects this country's current demographic status?

options.label: A
options.text: It is experiencing rapid growth and will double in 35–47 years

options.label: B
options.text: It is growing moderately with a doubling time of less than 70 years

options.label: D
options.text: It has slow growth and will double in more than 139 years

questions.correct_answer: B. It is growing moderately with a doubling time of less than 70 years
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is growing moderately with a doubling time of less than 70 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An AGR of 0.6% reflects moderate growth, with the population expected to double in less than 139 but more than 70 years — a key demographic indicator for planning health, education, and infrastructure needs.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with fever, cough, and chest pain. Chest X-ray reveals consolidation, and sputum microscopy demonstrates large, round, thick-walled yeast cells with broad-based budding and a double-contoured cell wall. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for his pneumonia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Blastomyces dermatitidis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blastomyces dermatitidis is identified in tissue by its broad-based budding yeast with a thick, double-contoured wall and is a known cause of fungal pneumonia in endemic areas.

questions.text: A 63-year-old patient with a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation is being evaluated for pharmacological rhythm control. The cardiologist wishes to prescribe an agent that prolongs the cardiac action potential duration by selectively blocking delayed rectifier potassium channels, without exhibiting additional sodium, beta-blocking, or calcium channel-blocking activity. Which of the following is the most appropriate agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dofetilide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dofetilide is a class III antiarrhythmic that selectively prolongs the cardiac action potential without affecting sodium, beta, or calcium channels, making it the purest action potential–prolonging agent.

questions.text: What obstetric complication is this test most specifically being developed to detect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pre-eclampsia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Congo Red Dot (CRD) test is a novel; rapid diagnostic test being evaluated for early identification of pre-eclampsia . It detects misfolded proteins in maternal urine that are pathognomonic for placental dysfunction. This low-cost, bedside tool may improve diagnosis and management of pre-eclampsia, especially in resource-limited settings.
  • ➤ The Congo Red Dot (CRD) test is a novel; rapid diagnostic test being evaluated for early identification of pre-eclampsia .
  • ➤ Congo Red Dot (CRD) test
  • ➤ pre-eclampsia
  • ➤ It detects misfolded proteins in maternal urine that are pathognomonic for placental dysfunction.
  • ➤ misfolded proteins
  • ➤ This low-cost, bedside tool may improve diagnosis and management of pre-eclampsia, especially in resource-limited settings.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to emergency with severe sudden-onset heart palpitations. The patient reports symptoms of chest pain, fatigue, and dizziness. Upon examination, his heart rate is 165/min and regular. His blood pressure is 106/74 mmHg. A gentle massage below the level of the left mandible elicits an immediate improvement in the patient, as his heart rate returns to 60/min. What was the mechanism of action of this manoeuvre?

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the refractory period in ventricular myocytes

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing sympathetic tone in systemic arteries

options.label: C
options.text: Decreasing the firing rate of carotid baroreceptors

questions.correct_answer: D. Slowing conduction in AV node
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Slowing conduction in AV node

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carotid sinus massage increases parasympathetic tone, leading to slowed AV node conduction and termination of supraventricular tachycardias such as AVNRT.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true characteristic of Duane Retraction Syndrome Type 1?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient experiences limited abduction and adduction

options.label: B
options.text: There is a widening of the palpebral fissure on abduction

options.label: C
options.text: Head tilt is more common than other types

options.label: D
options.text: Sixth nerve palsy is associated with this condition

questions.correct_answer: B. There is a widening of the palpebral fissure on abduction
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) There is a widening of the palpebral fissure on abduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Duane Retraction Syndrome Type 1 is characterized by limited abduction of the affected eye and widening of the palpebral fissure on abduction , caused by abnormal development of the sixth cranial nerve affecting the lateral rectus muscle.
  • ➤ Duane Retraction Syndrome Type 1
  • ➤ limited abduction
  • ➤ widening of the palpebral fissure on abduction

questions.text: A 22-year-old traveller returns from East Africa and is evaluated for fever, chills, and malaise. Blood smear reveals ring-stage parasites inside red blood cells. Further testing is ordered to confirm the species. The patient is found to be negative for Duffy blood group antigen. This genetic trait provides resistance against which of the following Plasmodium species?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Plasmodium vivax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plasmodium vivax requires the Duffy antigen to invade red blood cells; individuals lacking this antigen are naturally resistant to P. vivax infection.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman reports a sexual assault that occurred outdoors during heavy rain. She arrives at the emergency department 12 hours later, still wearing the same wet clothes. Which of the following is the most accurate about evidence collection from her clothing?

options.label: A
options.text: Wet clothing should be dried with heat before packaging to prevent bacterial degradation

options.label: B
options.text: Wet clothing should be placed in airtight plastic bags to preserve moisture-sensitive evidence

options.label: C
options.text: Wet clothing may still yield biological evidence but must be air-dried before packaging in paper bags

options.label: D
options.text: Biological evidence cannot be recovered from wet clothing due to dilution and contamination

questions.correct_answer: C. Wet clothing may still yield biological evidence but must be air-dried before packaging in paper bags
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Wet clothing may still yield biological evidence but must be air-dried before packaging in paper bags.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In forensic evidence collection, wet clothing with potential biological stains (e.g., semen, blood, epithelial cells) should be air-dried at room temperature and stored in paper bags , not plastic, to avoid bacterial growth and preserve DNA integrity. Proper handling ensures evidence remains admissible and testable.
  • ➤ In forensic evidence collection, wet clothing with potential biological stains (e.g., semen, blood, epithelial cells) should be air-dried at room temperature and stored in paper bags , not plastic, to avoid bacterial growth and preserve DNA integrity.

  • ➤ air-dried at room temperature and stored in paper bags
  • ➤ Proper handling ensures evidence remains admissible and testable.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman visits the emergency department with sudden onset dizziness, nausea, and difficulty maintaining balance. Recognizing the relationship between neck positioning and vertebral artery vulnerability is crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the effect of various mitochondrial toxins on cellular respiration and energy metabolism. questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida in active labor has her progress monitored using the partograph. Based on the partograph findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with E. coli septic shock is on vasopressors and ventilation. By day 4, serum creatinine rises from 1.1 to 3.2 mg/dL. Urine output falls despite stable BP. Urinalysis is shown. Which therapy has been proven to improve clinical outcomes in this setting?

questions.text: In a population of 20,000 adults, hypertension prevalence is 25%. Among hypertensives: Awareness: 50%, Treatment among those aware: 50%, Control among those treated: 50%. How many individuals in the total population have their hypertension under control?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) are correct? The absence of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors leads to the loss of decay-accelerating factor (DAF), predisposing cells to complement-mediated lysis. Intravascular hemolysis in PNH predominantly affects only red blood cells due to their high complement sensitivity. Flow cytometry showing absence of CD55 and CD59 on blood cells is used as a confirmatory diagnostic test for PNH. Thrombosis in unusual sites, such as hepatic and portal veins, is a major cause of mortality in PNH. Complement activation during REM sleep due to sympathetic overactivity is the key trigger of hemolysis in PNH.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Only 1, 3 and 4 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PNH is caused by the absence of GPI anchors, resulting in loss of complement regulatory proteins (CD55 and CD59), leading to complement-mediated lysis of all blood cell lineages. Diagnosis is confirmed by flow cytometry, and thrombosis in unusual sites is a major cause of mortality.
  • ➤ PNH is caused by the absence of GPI anchors, resulting in loss of complement regulatory proteins (CD55 and CD59), leading to complement-mediated lysis of all blood cell lineages.
  • ➤ Diagnosis is confirmed by flow cytometry, and thrombosis in unusual sites is a major cause of mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is/are correct? MPGN is characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with a tram-track appearance seen on staining. It commonly shows a linear immunofluorescence pattern due to anti-GBM antibody deposition. Type I MPGN features subendothelial immune complex deposits and is frequently associated with hepatitis B and C infections. Type II MPGN (dense deposit disease) is linked to an autoantibody that stabilizes C3 convertase, resulting in hypocomplementemia. MPGN typically responds well to corticosteroid therapy and rarely progresses to chronic renal failure.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above statements are correct

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3 and 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN) shows a granular IF pattern due to immune complex deposition, has subendothelial or intramembranous deposits depending on type, is associated with hepatitis viruses or C3 nephritic factor, and often progresses to chronic renal failure despite poor steroid responsiveness.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding sugammadex are correct? Sugammadex is a modified γ-cyclodextrin used to reverse neuromuscular blockade induced by depolarizing agents like succinylcholine. Sugammadex binds rocuronium or vecuronium in a 1:1 ratio at all levels of neuromuscular blockade. Compared to neostigmine, sugammadex provides a faster and more complete reversal of neuromuscular block.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Pediatric Advanced Life Support (PALS) during cardiac arrest are correct? The recommended compression rate is 100–120/min, pushing at least one-third of the anteroposterior chest diameter. If an advanced airway is placed, compressions should be paused for ventilation at a 15:2 ratio. For the first defibrillation attempt, 2 J/kg is recommended; subsequent shocks should be ≥4 J/kg, up to 10 J/kg max. The IV/IO dose of epinephrine is 0.1 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of 0.1 mg/mL), repeated every 3–5 minutes.

  • ➤ PALS guidelines:
  • ➤ PALS guidelines:
  • ➤ CPR Quality: Push hard (≥⅓ of anteroposterior diameter of chest) and fast (100–120/min) and allow complete chest recoil Minimize interruptions in compressions Change compressor every 2 minutes, or sooner if fatigued If no advanced airway, 15:2 compression-ventilation ratio If advanced airway, provide continuous compressions and give a breath every 2–3 seconds Shock Energy for Defibrillation: First shock 2 J/kg Second shock 4 J/kg Subsequent shocks ≥4 J/kg, maximum 10 J/kg or adult dose Drug Therapy: Epinephrine IV/IO dose: mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of the 0.1 mg/mL concentration). Max dose 1 mg. Repeat every 3–5 minutes. If no IV/IO access, may give endotracheal dose: 0.1 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of the 1 mg/mL concentration). Amiodarone IV/IO dose: 5 mg/kg bolus during cardiac arrest. May repeat up to 3 total doses for refractory VF/pulseless VT Lidocaine IV/IO dose: Initial: 1 mg/kg loading dose
